history.title: Our Story
history.lead: The story of Bulwark began not in an office, but through the meeting of a Ukrainian woman from Kharkiv and a Belarusian volunteer.
history.alisa_text: was born in Kharkiv. Until February 24, 2022, she lived an ordinary life, but after the invasion began, she went through shelling and evacuation. She returned to Ukraine with a firm decision: this is her home.
history.vlad_text: is originally from Minsk. In 2020, he went through repression and torture in Akrestsina. With the start of the Great War, he did not hesitate to go and fight for the freedom of Ukraine.
history.conclusion_1: Today, they are building the Bulwark Foundation together, uniting those who believe that freedom is everyone's right.
history.conclusion_highlight: ‚ÄúWe are returning. We are building a new Belarus!‚Äù
history.sec1_lead: For centuries, Belarus and Ukraine have existed side by side, sharing similar fates, trials, and threats. Both nations have passed through periods of statelessness and attempts to destroy their right to a future.
history.sec1_p1: At various times, Belarusians and Ukrainians were part of the same state entities‚Äîthe Grand Duchy of Lithuania and the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth‚Äîwhere their political traditions and ideas of freedom were formed. Throughout the centuries, both nations faced expansion from Moscow, and in the 20th century, policies of Russification and repression.
history.sec1_p2: History shows: when our peoples are divided, Moscow grows stronger. When we stand together, Europe‚Äôs line of defense becomes unbreakable.
history.modern_text: Belarusians who fight for Ukraine today understand: Ukraine's defeat would mean the end of hope for a free Belarus. We are natural allies by historical necessity.
history.photo_caption: Minsk, 2020. A photo as a symbol of unshakable will.
history.sec3_p2: When Russia launched its invasion on February 24, 2022, thousands of Belarusians made their choice‚Äîthey stood up to defend Ukraine as part of the Kastus Kalinouski Regiment and other units.
history.sec2_p1: In the 19th century, the uprisings of 1830-1831 and 1863-1864 united Belarusians and Ukrainians against the Russian Empire. The Soviet period brought the Holodomor to Ukraine and the destruction of the intelligentsia in Belarus.
history.sec2_p2: In 1991, both countries gained independence just one day apart. But their paths diverged: Ukraine moved toward democracy through Revolutions, while Belarus fell under the rule of Lukashenko.
history.sec2_p3: Today, history again puts us before a common enemy, and our response to this challenge will determine the future of the entire region for centuries to come.
history.sec3_p1: August 9, 2020, was a turning point. The regime responded with terror: tens of thousands of arrests, torture at Akrestsina. As of February 2026, more than 1,400 political prisoners remain behind bars.
